JUDGES: David Thór Björgvinsson;Giovanni Bonello;Ján Šikuta;Ledi Bianku;Nebojša Vučinić;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä
TEXT: The applicants are siblings . The first applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . The second applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE ( NORP Republic ) . The third applicant , ORG , was born in DATE and died in DATE . She was a NORP national . The first and the second applicants as her exclusive heirs expressed the wish to continue the application in the third applicant 's stead .
In DATE the first and second applicants appointed Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE , to represent them in the proceedings before the ORG .
The Government of GPE ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their successive Agents , PERSON and PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
CARDINAL . Proceedings for recovery of the applicants ' property
The applicants ' parents owned a plot of land of QUANTITY which had been allocated to them in DATE . The plot was used as an orchard .

In DATE the applicants ' father joined an agricultural cooperative . He put the above plot of land at the cooperative 's disposal . The cooperative thereby obtained the right of “ cooperative use ” in respect of the land . The owners retained the ownership title in the form of nuda proprietas .

In DATE the applicants ' father terminated his membership of the cooperative which , however , continued using the plot . Following a restructuring of ORG and exchanges of land between them , the plot was transferred to the GPE cooperative , which later merged with the GPE cooperative .

In DATE the GPE cooperative put the land at the disposal of ORG ( Slovenský zväz záhradkárov DATE “ the Union ” ) , free of charge , for a period of DATE . The area where the plot is located was turned into garden allotments consisting of individual gardens which were placed at the disposal of members of the Union . The land has since then been used by the gardeners .
In DATE the GPE ORG and the Union concluded a contract extending the ORG 's right to use the plot until DATE .
After their parents ' death the applicants acquired ownership of the plot by succession .

In a letter of DATE the president of the NORP cooperative expressed the view that , as the cooperative had acquired the applicants ' plot by exchange , the “ cooperative use ” regime did not apply to that land . In any event , the land could not be restored to the applicants as it was being used by gardeners in allotments . The ORG offered to put a different plot of land at the applicants ' disposal or , alternatively , to conclude a rent contract with them .
In DATE the applicants brought an action against the ORG claiming payment of rent for the use of the plot .

On DATE the ORG asked the applicants to indicate whether they maintained their claim . In DATE the applicants informed the court that they wished to claim compensation for unjustified use of their land by the gardeners . The applicants submitted no further information in respect of the proceedings concerning that claim .
On DATE the applicants sued the ORG and representatives of the CARDINAL allotments concerned . They claimed that the land should be returned to them .
On DATE ORG dismissed the action . ORG quashed that judgment and instructed the first - instance court to take further evidence . The case was transferred to ORG .
On DATE the applicants provided further particulars and explained that under LAW they sought a court ruling ordering the defendants to vacate their land .
On DATE ORG dismissed the action .

In the reasons for its judgment ORG , with reference to documentary evidence and witness statements , established that the above contract of DATE extending the gardeners ' right to use the land until DATE was void as it had not been duly signed by the parties ' representatives . However , that shortcoming had not affected the cooperative 's right to use the property . After the entry into force of LAW CARDINAL that right had been converted into a lease pursuant to LAW . The judgment further stated that as the applicants had not terminated the lease in respect of the defendants , their application for the land to be vacated could not be granted .

The applicants appealed . They argued that ORG had incorrectly found that the GPE cooperative had maintained the right of cooperative use of their plot . The applicants also alleged that they had given notice to the representatives of the gardeners ' allotments concerned in DATE and had requested them to vacate the property in DATE .

On DATE ORG upheld the first - instance judgment . While summing up the conclusions reached by ORG , ORG stated that , in the absence of any other agreement between the applicants and the cooperative , the latter was to be considered as renting the land from the applicants with effect from the entry into force of LAW DATE . It had not been shown that the applicants had put an end to that legal relationship .

In its judgment the court of appeal confirmed that the provisions of LAW DATE were applicable to the applicants ' land . They should have sought redress in accordance with that LAW , which was a lex specialis in respect of the general protection of ownership rights under LAW . The applicants ' action under the latter provision could therefore not be granted . In the judgment reference was made , inter alia , to sections DATE , DATE and DATE of LAW DATE .

On DATE the applicants brought an action before ORG against the CARDINAL allotments as an entity and their representatives . They claimed that the defendants should be obliged to refrain from any interference with the plaintiffs ' ownership rights . On DATE the ORG discontinued the proceedings as the applicants had failed to rectify formal shortcomings in their action , despite prior warnings and indications as to how to do so .
In the meantime , in DATE , the applicants gave notice to the representatives of the allotments of their intention to terminate the lease of their land as from DATE .

In DATE the applicants lodged a complaint under LAW in respect of the above judgments of DATE and DATE . They contended that the ordinary courts ' decisions had been arbitrary as the courts had disregarded the relevant evidence . In particular , the courts had overlooked the fact that the applicants had given notice to the defendants in DATE and DATE and that in the above letter of DATE the president of the GPE cooperative had confirmed that the latter had not acquired the right of cooperative use of the land . The applicants relied on the constitutional equivalents of LAW No . CARDINAL .

On DATE ORG declared the complaint inadmissible . It found no indication that the way in which the proceedings before the ordinary courts had been conducted and the conclusions reached by those courts were contrary to the applicants ' constitutional rights in issue .
On DATE the first and second applicants issued notice to the individual gardeners using their land , requesting them to vacate the land .
On DATE the first and second applicants informed the ORG that the gardeners were continuing to use their land .
CARDINAL . Proceedings under LAW .

On DATE the gardeners in the allotments requested that the tenancy and ownership relationship in respect of their gardens be settled by means of a land consolidation procedure under LAW . ( see “ Relevant domestic law ” below ) .

On DATE ORG rejected the request . On DATE ORG upheld that decision . The authorities found that the applicants ' land used by gardeners in the allotments did not fall under LAW . , as the gardeners had not shown that a valid contract entitled them to use the land . In particular , the DATE contract allowing the gardeners to continue using the land until DATE was void due to formal shortcomings . Reference was made to ORG judgment of DATE .
The decision became final on DATE .
CARDINAL . Administrative proceedings concerning gardeners ' huts
CARDINAL gardeners in CARDINAL of the allotments applied to the PERSON municipality for retrospective planning permission in respect of the huts they had built in the gardens .
The applicants objected , arguing that the gardeners had no rights of use over the land .

The municipal authority noted that the applicants ' objection related to their proprietary rights in respect of the relevant plots . In accordance with section CARDINALa of LAW DATE , read in conjunction with Article CARDINALc of LAW , such issues fell to be determined by a court . For that reason the PERSON municipality , on DATE , stayed the administrative proceedings pending the outcome of the judicial proceedings which the applicants were required to bring .

On DATE , on a request lodged by the first applicant , the PERSON municipality ordered the removal of several huts in a different allotment . The authority noted that the construction of the huts in issue had been permitted only temporarily until DATE on the condition that after that date the gardeners concerned would remove them at their own expense . On CARDINAL and CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed the appeals lodged by the gardeners .

CARDINAL of the gardeners sought a judicial review of the above administrative decision of CARDINAL DATE . The proceedings are pending before ORG which , on that ground , issued an injunction preventing the decision in question from being enforced .

Under LAW , owners have the right to protection against unjustified interference with their ownership rights by others . In particular , they are entitled to claim restitution of the property from those who hold it without any valid legal ground .

Article ORG entitles courts to determine landowners ' claims against persons who have constructed a building without permission on their plots . The courts can order the removal of such buildings at the expense of their owners ( paragraph CARDINAL ) , grant ownership of such buildings to the landowners against compensation ( paragraph CARDINAL ) or settle the relationship between the persons involved in a different way , in particular by granting an easement ( paragraph CARDINAL ) .
Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that every person is liable for any damage he or she causes by breaching an obligation resulting from law .
LAW CARDINAL entered into force on DATE .

Paragraphs CARDINAL ( a ) , ( b ) and CARDINAL of section CARDINAL provide that , as from the entry into force of the LAW , ORG ' right to use other persons ' land is revoked and , unless a different agreement is reached with the owners , the user of the land acquires tenancy rights thereto . This lease relationship can be terminated by notice given by DATE .

Under LAW ( CARDINAL ) , as in force until DATE , in cases where the land was used by individual gardeners in an allotment , the tenancy could not be terminated before the date until which the land was originally put at the users ' disposal . Unless the parties otherwise agreed , the gardeners had the right to have the tenancy extended by DATE .

Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) entitled the owners of land used by gardeners in allotments to request , within DATE from the entry into force of the LAW , that the land in question be exchanged for a different plot of land owned by the ORG .

The principal purpose of the LAW is to arrange for the return to the categories of persons referred to therein of agricultural property the ownership of which was transferred to the ORG or other legal persons in the circumstances specified in the LAW DATE and DATE . Section CARDINAL obliges the persons holding such land to return it to the original owners within DATE of the latter 's request . It also provides for a procedure in the event of refusal by the former to return the property . Under LAW ( CARDINAL ) ( d ) , land on which an allotment has been established can not be returned to the original owner .
Act PERSON . governs the use of land within allotments and the transfer of ownership rights in respect of such land . It repealed section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE with effect from DATE .
Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW provides that the users of land in allotments acquire the right to lease it as from the entry into force of the LAW .

The main purpose of the LAW is to permit the transfer of ownership of the land to gardeners in allotments where the majority of gardeners so request and where the owners oppose the transfer ( further details concerning the relevant provisions and the domestic practice are set out in GPE obec PERSON v. GPE , no . FAC , § § DATE and CARDINAL - CARDINAL , ORG DATE ... ( extracts ) ) .

Section CARDINALa governs proceedings concerning the approval of buildings constructed without permission . Where the owner of such a building can not prove that he owns the relevant plot or otherwise has title to it and where the owner of the plot disagrees with the construction being authorised , the administrative authority must refer the landowner 's claim to a court and stay the proceedings under LAW DATE pending the outcome of the judicial proceedings .
